pr_title: GEODE-7778: Add PUBLISH, SUBSCRIBE and UNSUBSCRIBE Redis commands

timeline.message:
GEODE-7778: Add PUBLISH, SUBSCRIBE and UNSUBSCRIBE Redis commands

Co-authored-by: Jens Deppe <jdeppe@pivotal.io>
Co-authored-by: Prasath Durairaj <vdurairaj@pivotal.io>
Co-authored-by: Murtuza Boxwala <mboxwala@pivotal.io>
Co-authored-by: Sarah Abbey <sabbey@pivotal.io>
Co-authored-by: John Hutchison <jhutchison@pivotal.io>
Co-authored-by: Ray Ingles <ringles@pivotal.io>

GEODE-7778: Add PUBLISH, SUBSCRIBE and UNSUBSCRIBE Redis commands

Co-authored-by: Jens Deppe <jdeppe@pivotal.io>
Co-authored-by: Prasath Durairaj <vdurairaj@pivotal.io>
Co-authored-by: Murtuza Boxwala <mboxwala@pivotal.io>
Co-authored-by: Sarah Abbey <sabbey@pivotal.io>
Co-authored-by: John Hutchison <jhutchison@pivotal.io>
Co-authored-by: Ray Ingles <ringles@pivotal.io>

timeline.bodyText: Does this mean that every RedisAdapter will have a PubSub instance, even if it is not required?
timeline.author: kohlmu-pivotal

replies.bodyText: Only one PubSub is created for the lifetime of the adapter. Each ExecutionContextHandler receives a reference to it.
replies.author: jdeppe-pivotal

timeline.bodyText: Why would this not be an Interface? Then at least there is the ability that one could have another implementation of this, without tightly coupling the code.
timeline.author: kohlmu-pivotal

replies.bodyText: I think that would definitely be a good thing if we find there is a need for multiple implementations. For now it's just a concrete class.
replies.author: jdeppe-pivotal

replies.bodyText: Can we then just add an interface and an implementation... It is easier to do this BEFORE rather than after. Also it makes it easier to achieve loose coupling.
replies.author: kohlmu-pivotal

replies.bodyText: Done
replies.author: jdeppe-pivotal

timeline.bodyText: Is this timeout an SLA or just best guess? What happens if a message takes 2s to send, is that bad? Maybe a timeout that can be either configured or maybe a little more lenient?
timeline.author: kohlmu-pivotal

replies.bodyText: Fixed code
replies.author: jdeppe-pivotal

timeline.bodyText: what is s here? I don't have an IDE to tell me what this is supposed to be
timeline.author: kohlmu-pivotal

timeline.bodyText: s = subscriber?
timeline.author: kohlmu-pivotal

timeline.bodyText: s = subscriber?
timeline.author: kohlmu-pivotal

timeline.bodyText: s = subscriber?
timeline.author: kohlmu-pivotal

timeline.bodyText: Seems we are lacking some consistency... Here we specifically name the param subscriber, but higher up we just call it s
timeline.author: kohlmu-pivotal

timeline.bodyText: Maybe some JavaDoc here.. what is this class and why do we care....
timeline.author: kohlmu-pivotal

timeline.bodyText: Why not a LinkedList if every operation is a "iterate" over all entries. No benefit to using ArrayList if you don't use the indexing or ordering.
timeline.author: kohlmu-pivotal

replies.bodyText: We're coding to the interface and not the concrete class. It could easily be changed if the need arises.
replies.author: jdeppe-pivotal

replies.bodyText: ArrayLists create heavier constructs under the hood, regardless of "I'm coding against that interface". All I'm asking is, given that you know you will never use  indexing, would a LinkedList not suffice?
replies.author: kohlmu-pivotal

timeline.bodyText: I wonder if one should expose the PubSub world here... maybe have the context have a publish method, which then delegates to the internal PubSub. To me it is a little like feature envy... Where instead of having the ExecutionHandlerContext handle the publish, we first have to know that there is a PubSub and then ask it to do work  -- https://refactoring.guru/smells/feature-envy
timeline.author: kohlmu-pivotal

replies.bodyText: It's a good point. We realize that context is very overloaded right now and we're planning on refactoring in the future.
replies.author: jdeppe-pivotal

timeline.bodyText: See same comment on the PublishExecutor. I don't think we should expose the PubSub here.
timeline.author: kohlmu-pivotal

replies.bodyText: Ditto above.
replies.author: jdeppe-pivotal

timeline.bodyText: See above in PublishExecutor and SubscribeExecutor
timeline.author: kohlmu-pivotal

replies.bodyText: Same ditto
replies.author: jdeppe-pivotal

timeline.bodyText: Maybe have a logger?
timeline.author: kohlmu-pivotal

timeline.bodyText: Maybe have a logger?
timeline.author: kohlmu-pivotal

timeline.bodyText: Maybe add Comparable onto the class. Then one does not have to go outside of "standard" Java conventions, but creating a isEqualTo method
timeline.author: kohlmu-pivotal
timeline.diffHunk:

+
+package org.apache.geode.redis.internal;
+
+import java.util.Arrays;
+import java.util.concurrent.CountDownLatch;
+import java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit;
+
+import io.netty.buffer.ByteBuf;
+import io.netty.channel.ChannelFuture;
+import io.netty.channel.ChannelFutureListener;
+
+class Subscriber {

replies.bodyText: I don't think that will work since Comparable only uses a single type and isEqualTo requires multiple types.
replies.author: jdeppe-pivotal

replies.bodyText: Yes thank you. I do see that now.
replies.author: kohlmu-pivotal

timeline.bodyText: Is this thread safe?
timeline.author: kohlmu-pivotal

replies.bodyText: Not really, but since this pattern is used throughout all the commands I think it would be better to make that change in a separate PR and cover all the commands.
replies.author: jdeppe-pivotal

replies.bodyText: Could we please raise one and address accordingly
replies.author: kohlmu-pivotal

timeline.bodyText: Is this thread safe?
timeline.author: kohlmu-pivotal

replies.bodyText: Ditto
replies.author: jdeppe-pivotal

timeline.bodyText: Is this thread safe?
timeline.author: kohlmu-pivotal

replies.bodyText: Ditto
replies.author: jdeppe-pivotal

timeline.bodyText: Maybe make this final, if you are going through all the effort of constructor initialization and private
timeline.author: kohlmu-pivotal

timeline.bodyText: Maybe treat the final String.valueof(d) as the else then at least it seams one have thought of all the combinations.
timeline.author: kohlmu-pivotal

timeline.bodyText: What about strings with "whitespaces"?
timeline.author: kohlmu-pivotal

timeline.bodyText: Why do we need to expose the PubSub externally?
timeline.author: kohlmu-pivotal

replies.bodyText: It is used by the various Executors that deal with pub/sub. Once ExecutionContextHandler is refactored, this should not be necessary.
replies.author: jdeppe-pivotal

timeline.bodyText: why is this package protected and not private? or even private final?
timeline.author: kohlmu-pivotal

timeline.bodyText: Everywhere where there are collections, streams are used. Why not here? Why not a collect function? Consistency...
timeline.author: kohlmu-pivotal

timeline.bodyText: I think this might be a little fragile. What happens if there are NOT 2 entries or even 0... What if there are no arguments and it is null?
timeline.author: kohlmu-pivotal

replies.bodyText: This function call is fairly tightly controlled - higher level calling methods should already ensure correct parameterization.
replies.author: jdeppe-pivotal

replies.bodyText: Can I quote you on this? Can we please add validation BEFORE invoking.
replies.author: kohlmu-pivotal

replies.bodyText: Added validation
replies.author: jdeppe-pivotal

timeline.bodyText: Why explicitly call registerPublishFunction if this can be done inside the constructor? Why is this method even required?
timeline.author: kohlmu-pivotal

replies.bodyText: It ensures that the PubSub instance is fully constructed before use - since the Function requires a reference to it.
replies.author: jdeppe-pivotal

replies.bodyText: Let me rephrase, given that there are no dependencies as input parameters, the registering of Functions can happen at construction time.
replies.author: kohlmu-pivotal

replies.bodyText: Done
replies.author: jdeppe-pivotal

timeline.bodyText: This initialization could have been done on line 263, where the field is declared.
timeline.author: kohlmu-pivotal

replies.bodyText: That is true.
replies.author: jdeppe-pivotal

replies.bodyText: But I don't see any immediate value in changing it.
replies.author: jdeppe-pivotal

replies.bodyText: Also, you can use new PubSub as the registerFunction can (and should) be called in the constructor of PubSub otherwise one is exposing knowledge that does not need to be exposed.
replies.author: kohlmu-pivotal

timeline.bodyText: This is very inefficient. First iterate over all subscribers to see if there is a match. Then iterate over all subscribers again to return a count. Maybe one can findSubscribers if count = 0 then add other wise return count
timeline.author: kohlmu-pivotal

replies.bodyText:
I'm not sure I understand. We need to know two things:
1 - has a client already subscribed to a channel
2 - how many subscriptions a client currently has
In order to address both of these concerns, the findSubscribers method would probably need to be inlined which seems like it would be less readable.
replies.author: jdeppe-pivotal

replies.bodyText:
You are correct.
That said.. What is the max number of Pub/Sub combinations we can expect? How does this approach scale?
Maybe two maps <channel,List> and <client,List> ?
replies.author: kohlmu-pivotal

replies.bodyText: Could we leave optimization until it's actually determined that it is needed?
replies.author: jdeppe-pivotal

replies.bodyText:
I agree, premature optimization.... But I'd be interested in what the "normal" usage on this would be. Maybe we add a load testing ticket on this, to see what load this construct can take. Is it 100's or 1000's or even 10,000's...
But I think it would be good to understand when it will slow down / break.
replies.author: kohlmu-pivotal

timeline.bodyText: Are we concerned about thread safety here or not? Because, if we would have done a count of all subscribers before adding, then we don't have to iterate all subscribers again just to in all reality do previousCount + 1
timeline.author: kohlmu-pivotal

replies.bodyText: I think that's just a different approach - also valid, but just different....
replies.author: jdeppe-pivotal

timeline.bodyText: There is no null checking happening. Can we really assume that the input channel and client are non-null?
timeline.author: kohlmu-pivotal

replies.bodyText: Null checking is handled by the respective equals methods.
replies.author: jdeppe-pivotal

replies.bodyText: So, you can 100% guarantee that the fields are ALWAYS non-null?
replies.author: kohlmu-pivotal

replies.bodyText: another approach is that the equals method is this.channel.equals(channel. This way the constructor can ensure that the instance channel field is non-null AND your isEqualsTo is null-safe
replies.author: kohlmu-pivotal

replies.bodyText: Yes, you're correct.
replies.author: jdeppe-pivotal

replies.bodyText: This implementation is not "optimal". If you makes sure the channel and client on the Subscriber is non-null, then your isEqualsTo method implementation changes. Then the comparison this.channel.equals(channel) && this.client.equals(client) is cleaner. There is no requirement to continually check if the method parameters are non-null, because it does not matter.
replies.author: kohlmu-pivotal

replies.bodyText: Fixed
replies.author: jdeppe-pivotal

timeline.bodyText: Would we not prefer a checked exception here?
timeline.author: kohlmu-pivotal

replies.bodyText: Removed this exception in favor of returning null
replies.author: jdeppe-pivotal

replies.bodyText: Removed the exception in favor of an explicit return
replies.author: jdeppe-pivotal

timeline.bodyText: Feature envy. Can we please change.
timeline.author: kohlmu-pivotal

replies.bodyText: I've raised GEODE-7793 (Refactor ExecutionHandlerContext to avoid 'feature-envy') to address this.
replies.author: jdeppe-pivotal
